page.title: 17CRANHAM CHURCH
page.content: Cranham Church is on the western edge of the village and overlooks the Painswick valley. It dates back to Norman times, a Norman arch being found above the entrance. It has a tower decorated with a shield with a pair of sheepshears on it. There are 7 yewtrees beside the path from the lych gate to the main door. In this gateway are 2 plaques commemorating those from Cranham and Prinknash who fell in the first world war, and those who served but survived. The bell of HMS Cranham, aminesweeper hangs in the gateway, which is the village's war memorial. There are several table top tombs and a vault for the Horlick's family who once lived in the village. The church can seat about 80 and is part of a united beneficeof 5 churches ministered by the Rector of Brimpsfield and an assistant.
